instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message:
Hi there,

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and I'm trying to diagnose an issue with the headphone socket. When I got this board, the computer wouldn't switch to the headphones when I plugged them in. After inspecting the board I noticed there were a few components that had been knocked off around the headphone socket: <RESISTOR>R6881</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6882</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6885</CAPACITOR>.

I replaced them, but the issue remained. I have found that if I have the headphones plugged in when I start the computer, they work fine, then if I unplug them while the computer is still on, it automatically switches back to the speakers, but if I plug the headphones back in again, the computer doesn't recognise them.

I would appreciate any suggestions.

Thanks in advance,
Bruce

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6700</RESISTOR>,2, <RESISTOR>R6801</RESISTOR>,2,3,4,6 all present and correct? Voltage on <TRANSISTOR>Q6800</TRANSISTOR> pin 2 and 5 and <TRANSISTOR>Q6801</TRANSISTOR> pin 5 with and without headphone plugged in. No need to boot OSX for these tests.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message:
Thanks for the quick reply.

All of those resistors are present and correct. The voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q6800</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q6801</TRANSISTOR> are as follows:

No headphones:
<TRANSISTOR>Q6800</TRANSISTOR> pin 2: 3.2V
<TRANSISTOR>Q6800</TRANSISTOR> pin 5: 0V
<TRANSISTOR>Q6801</TRANSISTOR> pin 5: 0V

With headphones:
<TRANSISTOR>Q6800</TRANSISTOR> pin 2: 0V
<TRANSISTOR>Q6800</TRANSISTOR> pin 5: 3.2V
<TRANSISTOR>Q6801</TRANSISTOR> pin 5: 3.2V

I think this part's working the way it should, yes?

Thanks again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message: Yeah that's fine. What is AUD_IP_PERIPHERAL_DET with and without headphone?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message: AUD_IP_PERIPHERAL_DET is 0V without headphones an 3.2V with headphones.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message: Also correct. Now it is gonna get annoying... what is a <SIGNAL>AUD_SENSE_A</SIGNAL> voltage with and without HP? Did you thoroughly check for any more damaged/missing components around HP jack and <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> headphone socket issue
threads.message:
I ended up replacing the audio port, and the problem is now solved. I think that while I was testing with the board in the case, it was creating some intermittent contact issues, resulting in the problems I was having. While I was testing with the board out, everything worked fine (hence all the positive results). 

Oce again Duke, thanks so much for your time. You can mark this one as "solved".

Bruce
